July 24, 1962
Mr. Loren B. Stone
Manager, KCTS-TV
University of Washington
Seattle 5, Washington
Dear Loren:
Thank you very much for sending along a carbon copy of your letter to Hy
Goldin. I am especially pleased because it so cogently affirms some things that
both Vernon and I have been telling Hy and John By strom, who will head up the
administration of the ETV legislation. Hy was rather startled and upset that we
did not embrace the idea of a national inter-connected ETV network as the major
goal of educational broadcasting. Bystrom, on the other hand , readily agreed that
the major emphasis—particularly if we are to have a viable ETV development-
must be on the state and local level.
I am also pleased to find myself in complete agreement with you again. I have
been a bit uncomfortable that we have not seen eye to eye, as has usually been our
wont, on the involvement of NAEB in ETV production. Actually, I have not been so
far apart from you as might appear. Your first memo was worded in such a way as to
suggest that this was a personal enthusiasm of mine. Not so. My interest, from
the first, has been merely to free NAEB from an absolute restriction. I never contem¬
plated the Association going into any large-scale production or distribution activity
and certainly not in the sense of competing with the Center. However, i would like
to be in a position to at least consider an occasional production opportunity if and
when it arises. The authorization by the Board to conduct two experimeri s in package
production provides that opportunity. This is merely authorization and it may well be
that we may never do any. Nevertheless, since the Board gave me the responsibility
for carrying out this activity, I felt I had the responsibility to explain this action;
consequently, 1 was necessarily placed in the position of a special advocate.
I know you feel very strongly about this matter, but I am frank to say was rather
irked by your unilateral action as a director of a particular region in distributing the
memo to the entire NAEB membership. In a way, this unilateral procedure, it seems
to me, is as lacking in democratic behavior as Brother Schwarzwalder’s precipitate
exist from the Board meeting when a vote went against him. I agree that insufficient
